constituent: grave, graveyard, flowers, sun, day, large, St. Bernard, soil, dirt, ground
heisigStory: The mounds of soil with crude wooden crosses set at their head suggests those boot-hill graves we all know from cowboy lore. The only odd thing about this kanji is that the soil comes UNDER the graveyard, rather than to its left, where we might expect. Just think of the bodies as "lying under boot-hill" if you have any trouble. By the way, this is not the first time, nor will it be the last, that we learn a kanji whose key word is the same, or almost the same, as a primitive element based on it, but whose shape differs somewhat. There is no cause to worry. By using the primitive in a variety of other characters, as we have done here, the confusion will be averted as a matter of course. In most cases, as here, the primitive element is taken from a part of the fuller kanji.
koohiiStory1: The soil under a graveyard is full of graves.
koohiiStory2: A grave is a patch of soil in a graveyard.
myStory: mộ. ko có đất nên chỉ có mộ.
